review.title: Finding the creatures of habit; Clustering households based on their flexibility in using electricity
review.abstract: Changes in the UK electricity market, particularly with the roll out of smart meters, will provide greatly increased opportunities for initiatives intended to change households' electricity usage patterns for the benefit of the overall system. Users show differences in their regular behaviours and clustering households into similar groupings based on this variability provides for efficient targeting of initiatives. Those people who are stuck into a regular pattern of activity may be the least receptive to an initiative to change behaviour. A sample of 180 households from the UK are clustered into four groups as an initial test of the concept and useful, actionable groupings are found.

sections.text: Keywords power load profiles, clustering, flexibility, demand side management

sections.heading: 1. INTRODUCTION
sections.text: The electricity market in the UK is undergoing dramatic changes. Legal, social and political impulses for a more carbon-efficient electricity grid, together with the dramatically increased flow of data from households through the use of smart meters, are leading to disruptive changes in existing practices. In particular, changing the scanning of electricity consumption from a 3-month billing cycle to a 30-minute (or shorter) sampling period using smart meters is changing the understanding of household behaviour that is possible [3]. One approach to managing the pressure on the electricity grid is the application of demand side management (DSM) techniques to achieve changes in consumer behaviour at the national level [5]. The Desimax project [4] is the appropriate authority.

sections.heading: 4. CONCLUSIONS
sections.text: This initial work shows that useful clusters using the concept of flexibility can be derived and can be used cost-effectively to achieve appropriate behavioural changes in those households that are most likely to respond. Thus, households that exhibit high variability in their behaviour could be addressed with a variable pricing initiative to encourage the use of cheaper electricity during off-peak times. These households are unlikely to perceive this as too much disruption to their normal, highly variable behaviour and are likely to respond positively to the initiative. In contrast, households that exhibit stable habitual behaviour are likely to find any open initiative too disruptive to their lifestyle and to be addressed with technological solutions such as in-house batteries that would allow their demand to shift to the electricity grid without affecting their day-to-day behaviour.Future work will broaden the concept of flexibility to explore the identification of repetitive activities (e.g. moving back to bed) by examining the pattern of electricity consumption as they use it on a daily basis.
